Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Who is that, This is... Hello, hello!... Who is that... Heinrich? This is Kringelein. Hello, Heinrich. This is Otto Kringelein. Hello! Can you hear me?... I've got to speak very quickly. I want to explain, but I must do so quickly, it costs so much. Please don't interrupt me -- hello? Hello! Listen! You know that will I made before my operation? I gave it to you. I want you to tear it up. Destroy it. Because, listen, I came to Berlin to see a great specialist about that old trouble of mine... It's pretty bad, Heinrich. The specialist says I can't live much longer.  I haven't long to live! That's what's the matter! Hello, hello. Are you on the line? No, it isn't nice to be told a thing like that. All sorts of things run through your head. I am going to stay here in Berlin. I am never coming back to Fredersdorf. Never! I want to get something out of life, too. You plague, and bother, and save -- and all of a sudden you are dead. Heinrich... You don't say anything. I am in the Grand Hotel, do you understand, the most expensive hotel in Berlin? I'm going to get a room here. The very best people stay here. Our big boss, Preysing, too. I saw him -- not five minutes after I was here. Sometime, I'd like to tell him exactly what I think of him. Listen, Heinrich -- I have taken all my savings; my life insurance, too; I cashed in all my policies, the sick benefit fund, the old age pension, the unemployment insurance, the burial fund and everything... What's that, miss?... Hello, Heinrich. I have to hang up now. I have to pay three times overcharge. Just think, Heinrich! There's music here all day long. And in the evening, they go around in full dress... Yes, sometimes I have pain, but I can stand it. Everything is frightfully expensive here. You can imagine, the Grand Hotel... What? Time's up...

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm a sick man -- Heinrich -- Hello - hello -- Operator -- every minute two marks ninety.

Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car... to be brought.

Dialogue: Oh -- good evening, Baron.

Dialogue: Well -- last night was not so good.

Dialogue: Yes -- but the audience.

Dialogue: The parquot loges are behind the parquet chairs.

Dialogue: Then they've put me back and I want to be up in front. How is that, chairs in front of loges?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: It's always so quiet here.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: If you occupied the room next to Madam Grusinskaya, you would appreciate the quiet of a hotel lobby.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: My dear sir, I would gladly change rooms with you.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: No doubt you would, Baron. But do you know, I'm quite indispensable to her. I'm her ballet master and her nurse. I hardly belong to myself anymore. But, there you are, it's Grusinskaya -- you can't help adoring her.

Dialogue: Mr. Preysing -- from Fredersdorf --

Dialogue: Mr. Preysing --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: No. No word.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I know -- I know.

Dialogue: For me?

Dialogue: No -- letters to two-eighty.

Dialogue: Any letters?

Dialogue: No, Doctor.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: No, Doctor.

Dialogue: The war dropped him here and forgot him.

Dialogue: It's a very nice room and inexpensive, sir.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Did I say I wanted a cheap room to live in -- when I came here did I ask for a cheap room? Did I?

Speaker: rohna
Dialogue: Just one moment, sir.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: No, I won't wait -- I can't -- Every day is precious -- every hour -- Every minute.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I came here because I wanted to live here, two weeks, maybe three -- God only knows -- I've told you I'll pay -- I'll pay anything you ask. I'm tired -- I'm ill -- I can't wait.

Dialogue: Has the gentleman a complaint?

Speaker: rohna
Dialogue: The gentleman is dissatisfied with room number five fifty-nine.

Dialogue: I certainly have a complaint -- and a fair one.

Dialogue: This gentleman can have my room.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh!

Dialogue: Send his bags up to my room.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- but -- I --

Dialogue: You're tired. I can see that.

Dialogue: Yes -- yes -- I am tired. I have been ill...

Dialogue: You are ill.

Dialogue: Certainly, sir.

Speaker: doctor

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Dialogue: Never?

Dialogue: Reducing?

Dialogue: No -- why? -- should I?

Dialogue: Lord no -- charming -- but why one meal a day?

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: Free --

Dialogue: Oh!

Dialogue: I can't dance tonight --

Dialogue: Let us cancel the engagement.

Dialogue: But, Madam. cannot do that.

Dialogue: -- Sergei -- dead -- Grusinskaya -- it's all gone.

Dialogue: Mon Dieu -- the pearls -- if they were to break --

Dialogue: The pearls won't break -- they hold together and bring me bad luck ---- I hate them!

Dialogue: Orchids come again, Madam -- no card -- I think perhaps they are from the same young man -- he is at the end of the corridor -- tall -- he walks like a soldier -- Madam must have noticed how often he is in the elevator with us. Last night for instance --

Dialogue: Oh, Suzette -- Suzette -- Sshh -- quiet.

Dialogue: Ah, oui -- the car is here for Madam.

Dialogue: It is not stage fright -- it's something more --

Dialogue: What -- what is it? Last night...

Dialogue: Last night?... There was no applause.

Dialogue: There was -- there was.

Dialogue: That theatre -- half empty -- dancing for those few -- I was frantic -- I finished -- the last beat and...  ...I waited -- I listened -- but the applause didn't come -- nothing. A man in the box -- and just the claques behind -- it is passed, Pimenov. We are dead -- it's finished.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: Meierheim --

Dialogue: What is this that you have cancelled your car? Who am I that I should wait like a fool at the door? And here on a whim, you cancel your car. Have you forgotten there is a performance? Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I'm cancelling the engagement.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Oh! Madam is cancelling the engagement. Madam has chosen a funny time for such a funny joke. Ha, ha, ha -- hurry, come on. Tonight -- there's a line in front of the theatre since six o'clock. The house is jammed to the roof.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: The house is not full -- Is it really full?

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Packed to the ceiling. Hurry -- get dressed. And what an audience -- the French Ambassador -- American Millionaires -- Princess Ratzville -- er -- er --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh -- but it can't be.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Oh, come, Madam -- please come.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: All right, Suzette -- quickly -- hurry.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: We will wait.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: You are late. Hurry.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Tell Madam Grusinskaya's chauffeur to bring the car.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: How is the house?

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Terrible. After this, no more ballets for me. Jazz --  Just jazz.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: If the house is empty again, I don't know --

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: When she gets her paint on and hears the music -- she'll be all right. I know these people.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You may laugh. Caviar and champagne may mean nothing to you, but to me -- they mean a great deal. You see, I'm ill and all of a sudden I got a fear of missing life. I don't want to miss life -- do you understand?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You are funny. You speak of life as if it were a train you wanted to catch.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes -- and for me, it's going to leave at any minute. Let's drink.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm sure this beautiful room must appeal to your taste -- distinctive, don't you think? Velvet upholstery -- 'A-number one'. I'm in the textile trade and I know.  And these are real silk drapes.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Silk -- think of that -- silk -- they are, too.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Have you seen the bathroom? -- Hot and cold running water -- You see, I can get a bath whenever I like.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: The stenographer!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Her master's voice!  I must go now -- goodbye -- thanks.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, don't go.

Dialogue: I'm engaged for the evening.

Dialogue: Oh, can anyone engage you for the evening?

Dialogue: To take dictation -- a Mr. Preysing --

Dialogue: What's the matter, Mr. Kringelein?

Dialogue: Baron, when I was sixteen years old, I started as an office boy in that man's factory --

Dialogue: Then you know him?

Dialogue: Do I know him -- I know him through and through.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I must -- I hope to see you again, Mr. Kringelein.

Dialogue: You will stay, Doctor -- if you have nothing better to do?

Dialogue: I have nothing better to do, Mr. Kringelein.

Dialogue: Perhaps you could present me now, Mr. Pimenov.

Dialogue: Please, Baron -- forgive me -- not now -- here she is.

Dialogue: Why not?

Dialogue: Take them back, Suzette.

Dialogue: You haven't time.

Dialogue: Hurry, Suzette.

Dialogue: Such nonsense.

Dialogue: The car for Madam Grusinskaya.

Dialogue: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: I'll see you in the morning then, at the conference. Everything'll be all right, Preysing... Don't worry. Goodnight.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Good night.

Dialogue: Both parties have fully agreed that this merger can result only in mutual advantages.

Dialogue: Moreover --

Dialogue: Moreover --

Dialogue: Is there a telegram for me yet?... Oh -- when it does, send it up.

Dialogue: Moreover...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Moreover...

Dialogue: No -- only occasional jobs.

Dialogue: Tired?

Dialogue: Moreover...

Dialogue: Moreover...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I don't see why it's unusual for a stenographer to be pretty -- if she does her work well, -- seems so silly. I don't know why they don't like girls like me in offices. Personally, I hate offices -- I'd much rather be in the movies.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Movies?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes, I photograph very well. Look --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I got ten marks for that.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Me.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Moreover...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What brown hands you have.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: That's from skiing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Skiing?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes... A man I know took me to Switzerland last month...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: A man? -- To Switzerland? -- That must have been nice -- for him.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Moreover... He was a lucky man -- that man.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Perhaps.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Don't misunderstand me. I'm a married man -- with grownup daughters. Uh --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Moreover -- Do you mind if I smoke?  I went to Florence once, too.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: With the same friend?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Moreover, the possibility of the successful termination of negotiations now pending with the Manchester Cotton Company...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Not too quickly.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You're a little too fast.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Can't you understand me?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I understand you perfectly.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Have you got it now?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Cotton Company --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Should throw a great weight into the balance...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: ...weight into the balance...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Telegram for Mr. Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Oh -- oh.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Deal with Manchester Cotton Company definitely off.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: How nice -- your daughters?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: My daughters -- yes, my daughters.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Is that Mrs. Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Definitely off.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh -- too bad. Did you quarrel?

Speaker: baron's voice
Dialogue: Come in!

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: You are late -- the dancer's gone to the theatre.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: She's gone to the theatre -- don't you know?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: And what are you going to do?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: The pearls are in her room.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Now listen to me. The others are getting suspicious of you. I was on the telephone to Amsterdam today, they think you're scared.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I've been careful, I've been waiting my chance.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: You've been waiting your chance. You're too much of a gentleman -- that's the trouble with you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I told you I'll get the pearls tonight.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Need any help?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Have you got that skeleton key?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No --

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: The floor clerk is out there in the corridor -- she sees everything ---

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: I could take care of her.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Chloroform on a handkerchief from behind -- while you...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No -- no -- no -- no...

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Poor girl -- chloroform would give her a rotten headache... I know -- I had it in the war. Besides, she's very pretty -- not young but --

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: You're no good for this business. It's just a joke to you...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I don't like your tone.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: No --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Get out and leave it to me... be ready to leave on the night train for Amsterdam...

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: With the pearls?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: With the pearls --

Speaker: loud speaker
Dialogue: 'You are listening to the music of the Eastman Jazz Band, in the famous Yellow Room of the Grand Hotel.'

Speaker: chambermaid
Dialogue: No -- no -- there is no one here.

Speaker: inspectress
Dialogue: You're late... What have you been doing?

Speaker: chambermaid
Dialogue: Everyone -- all the time says, 'Come back - come back.' They won't get out of their rooms.

Speaker: inspectress
Dialogue: No, Madame Grusinskaya is not here... The Western Theater?... No...

Speaker: suzette's voice
Dialogue: Have you seen Madame?

Speaker: clerk's voice
Dialogue: Isn't she at the theatre?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Hello, hello, Mr. Pimenov? Yes... Mr. Pimenov, have they found her?... No, she is not here... Yes, I'm at the hotel.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Wait till I see her, she'll pay for this -- this little trick is going to cost Grusinskaya a suit for breach of contract.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madame is ill -- her nerves...

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Her nerves... What about my nerves?... Who is she anyway? Where does she think she is -- Russia? Those days have passed.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madame --

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I want to be alone.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Where have you been?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Should I -- Does madame wish...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Suzette, please go, I want to be alone.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: I suppose I can cancel the Vienna engagement.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I wish to be alone.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: You'll be very much alone, my dear madame. This is the end.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: The end -- over -- finished --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: The Western Theatre --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Western Theatre?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: The stage -- Mr. Pimonov -- the ballet master... Grusinskaya -- hurry -- hurry.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes -- yes, I'm waiting.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Hello, Pimenov? -- I'm at the hotel. I couldn't go on -- I couldn't... No, no don't --  They didn't miss me -- good night, Pimenov...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Please, do not be alarmed, Madam.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Careful -- there's broken glass on the floor.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Please do not be frightened, Madam.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: What do you want here?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Nothing -- only to be here.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Why do you hide in my room?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: But surely you must know -- because I love you.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Because you love me -- you love me?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Poor little Grusinskaya! Does it do you good to cry? Are you afraid? Shall I go?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I was so alone -- always alone -- and suddenly you were there and said that.  No. I am not afraid. It is strange.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Don't cry -- it tears my heart to see you sob like that.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Nerves -- just nerves. You must forgive me. I have had a bad evening. I am very tired. Do you know what it is to be tired -- tired of a routine existence?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm afraid not -- I usually do just what I feel like doing at the moment.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: So you feel like coming into a lady's room -- and you come... What now?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'd like to smoke a cigarette.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Why do you look at me like that?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I did not know you were so beautiful... and --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: And then --?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No irony. You're so appealing -- so soft -- so tired. I feel like taking you in my arms and not letting anything more happen to you -- ever.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: And -- and --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: How tired you are!

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes -- tired...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: So alone.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Alone. All alone.  Oh, you strange -- strange creature.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: You mustn't talk Russian to me.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Strange man...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Am I quite strange to you?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Not quite strange now. It is as if I had been expecting you. You know, once when the Grand Duke was alive, I found a man hiding in my room -- a young officer --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: And...?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: He disappeared. Later he was found dead.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I never knew it was so dangerous to hide in a woman's room when she's alone.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Go away. Who are you --?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: A man who could love -- that is all, who has forgotten everything else for you.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: You could love me. It is so long since I have heard that word. Nobody has loved me for a long time. It is so icy-cold to be famous. One is so cruelly alone. How is it that you -- Let me look at you. Your hands. Your eyes. Why could you love me?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I saw you just now -- then I saw you cry -- and now I see you in the mirror -- Grusinskaya...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Grusinskaya... Oh -- oh if you knew how I slaved and slaved for Grusinskaya -- for the success of Grusinskaya -- for the triumph of Grusinskaya... and what is she now? Just someone who has found that on the day success ceases life ceases -- Are you listening to me -- Do you understand? -- I want you to understand.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yes -- I do understand.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I think you must go now -- the key is on the floor.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm not going -- You know I'm not going -- Let me stay here?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I want to be alone.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: That is not so -- you don't want to be alone.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I want to be alone --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No -- You don't want to be alone at all -- You were in despair before -- If I left you, you'd feel worse than you did before, You must not be alone -- You mustn't cry -- you must forget... Tell me that I can stay with you -- tell me.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Just for a minute then.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: What? Say it again -- I didn't hear.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: You -- man...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Thank you -- you are gallant.  What a sentimental scene. Grusinskaya weeping is a sight worth seeing. It is many years since she did such a thing... You frightened me -- badly. You're responsible for this -- painful scene.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: The stage frays one's nerves... the discipline -- it's so exacting. Discipline means doing what you don't want to do and take no pleasure in doing. Do you know what I mean? Have you ever experienced the weariness that comes from discipline?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I? -- Oh, no. I do only what I take pleasure in doing.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I see -- you do only what you take pleasure in doing. You take pleasure in coming into a woman's bedroom and you come. You take pleasure in a dangerous climb onto a balcony, so you do it... And what is your pleasure now?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I should like to smoke.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Why do you smile?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Because I can see something in the mirror that you cannot. My dear --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: What can you see?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: You are beautiful!

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Beautiful but so sad. I did not know it was so dangerous to look into a woman's bedroom.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I think you had better go now. The key is on the floor.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm not going... You know that I'm not going... Do you think I could leave you alone here? After that --?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: The veronal -- you. I'm going to stay here with you.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I want to be alone.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: That is not the truth.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: No -- oh, no!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Just for a minute, Grusinskaya --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, but Doctor. Isn't this wonderful. To live -- to live -- in the Grand Hotel.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: The Grand Hotel.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, but Doctor. The music -- the champagne -- girls when they dance -- all the shining ice in those big silver things -- That's life --

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Life! -- Mr. Kringelein, you are drunk -- good night.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: But Doctor --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Mr. Kringelein -- you are drunk -- good night.

Speaker: baron's voice
Dialogue: I've never been as happy.

Speaker: gru's voice
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: baron's voice
Dialogue: I've never been as happy!

Speaker: grusinskaya's voice
Dialogue: Say it again -- say it!

Speaker: baron's voice
Dialogue: I have never been so happy!

Speaker: girl one
Dialogue: Grand Hotel -- good morning -- no, Baron von Gaigern's room does not answer... Yes,... all right... Baron von Gaigern's chauffeur calling.

Speaker: girl three
Dialogue: Good morning, nine-thirty Doctor Otternschlag... No, Doctor, no messages... No, Doctor.

Speaker: girl five
Dialogue: Grand Hotel -- good morning... who is calling Madam Grusinskaya?... Oh, Mr. Pimenov. Madam Grusinskaya is not to be disturbed, sir... no, sir... yes, sir --

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Mr. Preysing's calls to one sixty two for today.

Speaker: girl eight
Dialogue: -- good morning... Mr. Preysing --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Nine-thirty, Mr. Preysing keeps us waiting.

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: He likes to play the great man.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: The Preysing stock is holding its own today on the market.

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: Ask Preysing what it's costing him to keep it up.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: And ask me what it's costing us to hammer it down.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: If the Preysing people get the Manchester contract, we shall certainly merge with the Preysing company -- but if they haven't they're ruined -- Preysing will have to declare himself.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Shhh -- here he is now.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen -- Mr. Preysing will be here in a minute.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen.

Speaker: men
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Sorry I'm late, I've been waiting for Justice Zinnowitz, my legal advisor.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Oh -- ho -- you want legal aid against us? -- The whole thing seems to me to be very simple.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Very simple -- I've always liked the way you dressed, Preysing -- English, isn't it?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: They turn out marvelous material in Manchester.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Manchester -- yes. Yes, yes, they do. Yes -- Now gentlemen shall we begin at the beginning? -- Have we cigars -- water and everything?

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: Manchester is a very interesting city, don't you think so, Preysing?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Manchester -- yes -- yes. A man in the textile industry naturally has to know Manchester.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: There's a lot of business to be done with the Manchester Cotton Company. They've the whole English market right in their hands. Have you any connections with -- Manchester?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: We have a good many connections in England, naturally.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: I mean with the Manchester people?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: We are here to discuss our merger. Naturally I can make no statement at this time. We must begin at the beginning.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Since, on the eleventh of June, this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger between our respective firms was entered into -- both parties have fully agreed that this merger can result only in mutual advantages.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'm laying before you the last general statement of our concern. Active capital, plant and machinery, raw material and finished product -- for instance -- mop rags --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Mop rags --!

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: What we want to know about is Manchester.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Preysing -- that's what we want to know.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'd like to wait for Justice Zinnowitz, before I commit myself.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Oh -- Preysing, Preysing --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: No water -- What a place!

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: All you have to do is phone for it.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Water -- seltzer, three or four bottles and cigars -- good ones.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: I can see this session is going to be exhaustive.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Now to proceed with the projected merger, the advantages for the Saxonia are so obvious...

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Oh -- now let's talk like adults. You want to tell us now a along story of what your factory can do. We know all that you could tell us and if you tell the truth it wouldn't sound so good. When you first approached us...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: We did not approach you.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Letter on file September fourteenth would show that you approached...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: It isn't so -- this was a response to a tentative feeler of your own.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Tentative my foot -- a month before this your old father-in-law came very privately and scratched at my door.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Scratched --  We did not take the initiative.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Of course you took the initiative.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen -- I see the conference is already underway.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Oh, here you are, Justice Zinnowitz -- I'm at cross-purposes with these gentlemen -- will you clear up the situation?

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: But the situation is perfectly clear, If you will allow me --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: How clear is Manchester?

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Foggy -- frightfully foggy, always, I'm told.  Have you said anything about Manchester, Mr. Preysing?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I can make no statement about Manchester at this time.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Well -- gentlemen.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Since, on the eleventh of June of this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger...

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Thank God we're beginning at the beginning.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: As you remember it -- when you approached us...

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: We did not approach you.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I know you did -- I said you did --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: And I said we didn't.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: And I know we didn't.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition was in my blood -- no rest, no stopping. We were drilled like little soldiers -- We danced in the school of the Imperial Ballet, in St. Petersburg. I was little and slim but hard as diamond -- a duty machine -- No rest, no stopping. And then -- I became famous and whoever is famous is alone... But why should I be telling you this? Last night I did not know you at all -- who are you, really? -- I do not even know your name.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My mother called me Flix.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Flix. -- And how do you live? What kind of a person are you?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep of a white flock -- I shall die on the gallows.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Really, I haven't a bit of character. None at all.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: When I was a little boy I was taught to ride and be a gentleman -- at school, it was a monastery, I learned to pray and lie -- and ---

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: And then, in the war, to kill and hide. That's all.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: And what do you do -- now?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large like a happy pig, devouring anything of life that pleases me, I really belong in jail

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: That's a silly joke.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: What is the matter?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Flix!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Did you come here just -- just for that? Oh -- it's horrible.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I don't want them now.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I'll not denounce you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: So --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I wanted money desperately -- Can you understand? -- That's why I wanted the pearls. I was threatened -- I was desperately in need of a certain big sum of money. I've been following you -- I've admired you. But I have forced myself not to think about you -- Last night, at last, I managed to came into your room and -- and now.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: And now?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I couldn't go through with it.  Remarkable.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Do you understand?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes -- yes -- yes.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Quickly -- here.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Good morning, Suzette.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Good morning, Madam.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam has slept well?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh, yes, Suzette.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam will dress now, it is late.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Five minutes, Suzette, come back in five minutes. I'll ring.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Yes, madam Suzette knows all about it.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam is beautiful this morning.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes, Suzette.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: You must go now.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: There -- it begins.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Hello -- hello -- Meierheim? Yes...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: No --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: What?... Cancel Vienna?... Are you mad? We always have great success in Vienna... Certainly not. Come here and see me... yes... good-bye.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: There -- the day begins... I must go to rehearsal.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Grusinskaya --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: You do believe that I really love you?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd die after last night.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I want to be good to you -- madly good.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Suzette will be back here in a minute.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'll go -- good-bye.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Shall I see you again?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Suzette will be back here any minute.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: When are you leaving Berlin?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Very early in the morning.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: For Vienna?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you come too -- I think it would be better -- for us -- for us both.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Oh -- yes but -- later.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Why later?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I have no money now -- I must get some first -- I must get some.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I'll give you what you need -- I have money.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Oh no -- that would spoil everything. I'll -- I will manage somehow -- I'll manage myself. I will go with you. When does the train leave?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a whole day. I'll be on that train.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I shall dance and you'll be with me and then -- listen -- After that you will come with me to Lake Como, I have a villa there. The sun will be shining. I will take a vacation -- six weeks -- eight weeks. We'll be happy and lazy. And then you will go with me to South America -- oh!

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: You must go now. Be careful on your way to your room.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'll go. -- I love you.  I'll be on that train. I'll get the money.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Don't do anything foolish -- I'm alarmed about you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Don't worry. I'll be on the train.  He leaves.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes, Pimenov... Yes... where are you, in your room? Come, I will see you now... hurry.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Not that dark dress -- something light -- bright -- it's a sunny morning, Suzette.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Good morning, Pimenov.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: Good morning, Gru -- your --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Pimenov, I have an idea -- a new ballet -- it must have mad music -- I'll explain it to you later. But now, hurry to the theatre -- I want full rehearsal -- properties -- full ballet and some musicians. Hurry -- Quickly. I will be there --

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: Gru -- you are positively radiant.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Yes, Pimenov.  One minute, Suzette, I will call you.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Hello -- will you -- will you get me Baron von Gaigern, please... yes... Baron von Gaigern -- yes...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Cherie... yes... it is you... nothing... good morning, good morning, cherie... nothing... no... just to tell you I'm happy.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Step back please.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: I've told you three times -- Baron von Gaigern is out.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Did he leave any message for me?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: No, he did not -- there is no message.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Any letters?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: No, doctor.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, Doctor, such a day -- such a day!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: For Madam Grusinskaya.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya -- at once --

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Your chauffeur's been waiting, Baron.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Baron, we must have gone a hundred miles an hour, at least...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yes, quite.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: We've been together all day... and in an aeroplane.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Life is changing you, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes, thanks to the Baron. The best shops, the very best. Look, Doctor, silk -- feels so nice on the skin... a London hat, see -- made in England, that's silk, too -- fifty marks... Look, the price is on it. That was half my salary before. The Baron is a very fine gentleman -- no one in my life has been so nice to me as the Baron.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm going to change and we'll meet for a drink in the Yellow Room.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: In the Yellow Room, where the music's playing and the ladies are?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Where the music's playing and the ladies are...

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: No pain, Mr. Kringelein?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Pain? Oh, no, Doctor. I think if I had pain I'd be too happy to notice it...

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: ...and let me say again for the tenth time...  ...you people were quite ready for the merger. You declared yourselves... fully agreed on all the terms -- Why should the signing of these articles be suddenly held up?

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: I've admitted that at one time we had reason for desiring ther merger -- What reason have we now? The Preysing Company has fallon upon evil days, very evil days.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Evil days -- I've shown you here --  -- my company exports to the Balkans alone, sixty-five thousand marks worth of mop rags a year.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Mop rags -- mop rags -- we're interested in something quite different!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: Shall I tell them again?

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Why waste time -- it's getting late.

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: You see -- what we are interested in --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Ah, come on -- we're going home.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Mr. Preysing has too scrupulous a regard for certainties...

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: You've talked enough today, you're hoarse now.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Sorry, Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You've decided against the merger?

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Yes --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Then, it's all over?

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Yes --

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: Well -- well -- You could call my office.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull through. This is a very bad time to be in such a crisis. We've...

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Oh no -- no -- the session is over. Let's go, it's off. Thank you, gentlemen.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: If you actually have news from Manchester then...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I am now free to announce...  ...that the deal between my firm and the Manchester Cotton Company has been successfully negotiated.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Preysing, you're joking with us.

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: You're a deep one.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: In that case give us the articles. We'll sign at once. We know all the details...

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I thought we'd suspended negotiations, gentlemen.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Under these circumstances it's quite a different matter.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Under these circumstances we might refuse to sign.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Come on -- business is business -- Come on --

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: Here's my signature -- here Preysing, sign here.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: What a session this has been.

Speaker: schweimann
Dialogue: It's twenty-five to six.

Speaker: waitz
Dialogue: We should celebrate this with a bottle of wine.

Speaker: gerstenkorn
Dialogue: See you soon, Preysing. Next week we'll meet and discuss further details.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Next week.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Next week.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: You let me talk till I'm hoarse and you had Manchester sewed-up all the time. Why?

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Well -- the deal has been put through.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes, it has been put through -- it has been put through.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: What's the matter with you?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: What's bluff?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: That.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: 'Deal with Manchester definitely off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have thought it of you.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: No one would have thought it of me. I've been getting rusty in Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what the world wants I guess I can put up as big a bluff as anyone. From now on...

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: You must go to Manchester at once yourself and really see it through.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was desperate -- Now I don't care -- This sort of thing goes to a man's head.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: What you need is some relaxation.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd like to tear loose -- I'd like a drink. I'd like to go down to that dancing place. I'd like to start something.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: I can understand that -- after your -- uh --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's the first time in thirty years that I've ever... Where's that stenographer? Miss Flaemm...

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: What do you want with her?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I want to see her, I want to do some dictating -- report of the conference for my father-in-law.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: She had an engagement in the Yellow Room at five o'clock -- she was in a hurry.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Zinnowitz, would you say she was pretty?

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Pretty as a picture.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Let's go down and find her -- I need a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz.  I don't know anything about women -- been married for twenty-six years.

Speaker: zinnowitz
Dialogue: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does it. Goodnight.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Aeh!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Hello... Father-in-law?... Is that you?... The agreement is signed -- I did it... yes, father-in-law... but now I must go to Manchester.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: For you, Mr. Kringelein?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: For me? -- Oh, please, something sweet and cold.

Speaker: barman
Dialogue: A Louisiana flip, sir?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: A Louisiana flip, that sounds very nice -- sweet, eh? --

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: What do you do in the Grand Hotel? Eat -- sleep -- loaf around -- do business -- flirt a little -- dance a little. A hundred doors to one hall and nobody knows anything about the person next to him. When you leave another takes your room and lies in your bed -- the end.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr. Kringelein -- Where's the Baron?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm waiting for him here. The Baron and I have been together all day. A hundred miles an hour -- in a motor car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was marvelous --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Mr. Kringelein -- How you have changed, you look so nice.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh, please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me, Miss Flaemm, won't you have something sweet -- a Louisiana flip.  A Louisiana flip.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: No - absinthe.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes -- that --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You like music?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man might --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: A man might what?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I don't know -- I'd like to do anything --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh -- you would!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Hello -- sorry I'm late.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- here you are, Baron. A drink -- A Louisiana flip?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Kringelein. How do you feel now?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: A little strange, Baron.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I'd given you up.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: A drink, Baron -- A Louisiana flip?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No thanks -- keeping my head clear.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Dance then?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: She's beautiful -- isn't she?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Oh -- there are plenty of women.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: What have you been doing all day?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Chasing around.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Chasing what?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Money.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You were very different yesterday.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yesterday -- yes -- that was yesterday.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting what you're looking for?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: What, Doctor?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: A masculine paradise -- drink, the ladies, dancing...

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I had a very good opportunity, a young lady asked me to dance -- I ought to be able to dance, it seems to be very important.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: You must learn as quickly as your time allows -- Believe me Mr. Kringelein, a man who isn't with a woman is a dead man.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you all alone in the world.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: I'm always alone -- I have been everything.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Everything?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: I was sent as a military surgeon to South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken prisoner. Home on parole not to fight. I was a surgeon in the Great War till the end. Grenade in the face. Carried diphtheria bacilli in the wound until 1920. Isolated two years.  I've been everything.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: That was lovely.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Will you do me a big favor?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I'll do anything for you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Would you like to make a man happy?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes -- I'd love to.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Then dance the next number with Kringelein.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I feel sorry for him.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You're not a bit like you were yesterday.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I fell in love last night -- the real thing.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh -- there's no real thing -- it doesn't exist.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I thought that, too -- but I found that it does. Come along, dance with Kringelein.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Anything for you.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Miss Flaemm.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Hello!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Presently, Mr. Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: It's urgent.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Pardon me, the lady has urgent business here with me.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Insolent -- Berlin manners.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I wish you a very good evening, Mr. Preysing. You are staying here, too, Mr. Preysing?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- you must know me -- Kringelein at the plant. Assistant bookkeeper, building C, room twenty-three -- third floor.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Come and dance with me, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm -- business.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Tomorrow morning.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: No -- now.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Do you gentlemen know each other, Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing -- Baron von Gaigern.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend and not accept your invitation to dance.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I could not think of not accepting.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You say that you are employed by us in Fredersdorf, and here you are in Berlin, indulging in diversions which ill befit your position and which are very much beyond your means -- Quite extraordinary, Mr. Kringelein, I think we will look into your books.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Now, children, no fighting -- save that for the office. Let's have our dance.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Oh, let the poor devil alone.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I did not ask your advice.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I think it would be much better if you went away.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: We shall see who remains here the longer.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: As you will.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You must look at my face and not at the floor.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You're trembling.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I never danced before -- in public.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You dance splendidly.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: For the first time in my life, I'm happy.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Let's stop -- I'm tired.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Thank you, Miss Flaemm.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You may go, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Does the world belong to you, Mr. Preysing?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What is this insolence?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Do you think you have free license to be insulting? Believe me you have not. You think you're superior, but you're quite an ordinary man.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Go away -- go away.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Please -- please!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You don't like to see me enjoying myself.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Who are you? -- An embezzler most likely.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: An embezzler -- you're going to take that back, right here in the presence of this young lady -- who do you think you're talking to? You think I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You're discharged.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get out -- you're discharged.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You can't discharge me -- I'm my own master now -- at last. I'm ill, I'm going to die -- do you understand? I'm going to die very soon. Nothing can happen to me now. Nobody can do anything any more to me. By the time you can have discharged me I shall have been dead already.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Come, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I shall see you in the lobby in half an hour.

Speaker: house detective
Dialogue: Better let him stay -- I've sent for the Baron... How's your wife coming along?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: I was at the hospital all night walking up and down the corridor. They wouldn't let me in to see her. She has the pains, but the child doesn't come and I have to stay here chained to this desk.

Speaker: house detective
Dialogue: It will be all right.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: I hope so.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Did you send that page?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: The young lady's there, sir.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Sit here.  Cognac -- for you?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'm going to keep an eye on that Kringelein fellow. I'll find out where he gets the money to hang around the Grand Hotel.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Well -- you want me?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I must go to England -- at once.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You see, I'd like to take a secretary with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody -- I don't know if you quite understand me. You said you have travelled with gentlemen -- and I mean --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I understand perfectly.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: What do you think your salary would be -- for such a trip?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Wait -- I must figure it up.  First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes -- it's cold in England in March, I'll need a suit... You'd want me to look nice?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Of course -- of course.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: A thousand marks --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: It's agreed -- I will get a room here for you.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I can get a room here in the Grand Hotel for you.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Can you pay some attention to me?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Insolent young cub!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You mean Baron von Gaigern?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Baron!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Well, he's a gentleman!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: The Baron is tired?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just --  Well -- well --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could go to the Casino -- the place we passed with the marvelous bright lights?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't -- I am broke!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I've quit.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: You can't.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'm not going to get those pearls and neither are you.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: What about the money?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I'll pay you back.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I have an idea working in my head...

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: You might find a bullet through that head...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: If you did that, you'd get nothing except the police after you. If you wait -- I'll give you your six thousand back --

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car -- Madam Grusinskaya's car.

Speaker: inside porter
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car --

Speaker: megaphone
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Go on please -- go on, Suzette.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Bless you...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh -- I shall dance tonight -- How I shall dance -- I want to feel that you are in the theatre.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No! I can't explain now. Oh, look -- the pearls. You wear them now...

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Why do you think --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: They've brought me such good luck -- you --

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I'm worried about you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Don't.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: On the train?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Yes -- I will be on the train.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Till then.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Bless you --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Was the Baron joking, or is it really true that the Baron is -- in financial straits.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Absolutely true, Kringelein and I have to raise some money immediately.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: If the Baron -- if you would permit me --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I would be awfully glad to oblige, you've been so decent to me. Three hundred?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: If I could get into a game I might win some.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Gambling! I'd like that. I have over six thousand eight hundred marks with me.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: If we could scare up some men to play.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: We could come to my room.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Good!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Going?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Ready, Kringelein?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Ready, Baron.

Speaker: baron's voice
Dialogue: All right, gentlemen.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: I play -- I play -- Here -- Up -- Playing --

Speaker: kringelein's voice
Dialogue: Yes -- me.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Is that too much, Baron?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: No -- not at all.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: All right then.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: All right then.

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Don't show them.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: What do I do now?

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Turn 'em up.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh yes -- that's right -- look! I win, don't I --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: There you are gentlemen.

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Will you take the bank, sir?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes -- I'll take everything gentlemen -- please, let us drink -- champagne --- champagne is expensive and good. I'm winning more than I used to earn in a year -- double what I used to earn.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Where is the Baron -- where are you, Baron?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Excuse me, gentlemen.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: I'll take the bank -- All right, gentlemen.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: That was my last.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You've lost everything?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I've no luck.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again...

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my last chance.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: It's good, -- come along, Baron.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I take five hundred.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: All of that at once, Baron?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Eight.

Speaker: doctor's voice
Dialogue: Nine.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: That's it. The luck's with you.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Come along, Mr. Kringelein. Sit here.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm having luck for the first time in my life.

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Your bank, Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Out, Baron?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Look at that.

Speaker: kringelein's voice
Dialogue: I've won again, Baron -- I've won again.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Baron, I drink and win -- I drink and win -- I win and drink!

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: There are complaints in the hotel about the noise.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: What time is it? Getting late? Let's break it up!  You've been very lucky... Where's my coat? Let's go. He's drunk anyway!... Goodnight, Baron. Let's wind up the game, I'm broke and tired; you can't play against him. I put my hat down here, somewhere. I think I'll have a drink before I go. By the way, I've got to see you tomorrow morning. How've you been, Doctor?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, don't go, gentlemen! -- Stay a while.  Be my guests!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I oughtn't to presume, but I --  I'm so grateful to you -- it's been so marvelous. The first time in my life I have gambled -- I've danced! Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but it's the first time in my life I've ever tasted life!

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Splendid!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but very dangerous. You must have courage for it, then it's wonderful. You gentlemen don't know that because you are all healthy and happy, but I -- believe me -- a man must know death and not until then does a man know anything about life.

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: Rejoice in life while yet the small lamp burns.

Speaker: a man
Dialogue: It's a short life and a gay one...

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Drunk.

Speaker: another man
Dialogue: Poor fellow.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: He's a doctor -- The doctor's here -- He's just drunk!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Gentlemen, this man is ill -- very ill -- if you will leave.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Certainly, Doctor. Goodnight! Goodnight, Baron! Bad luck!

Speaker: drunken man
Dialogue: He's not used to champagne -- why does he drink it?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Can I help, doctor?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: No, the Baron will stay.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It will be over in a minute.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Over -- over so soon -- it has just begun.  Oh, the pain.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Try and sleep, Kringelein, don't be afraid.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'd like to live a little longer but -- I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...

Speaker: kringelein's voice
Dialogue: My pocketbook... my money in it...

Speaker: doctor's voice
Dialogue: What do you say -- what?

Speaker: doctor's voice
Dialogue: You what -- Oh, isn't it there?

Speaker: kringelein's voice
Dialogue: No -- But no I -- Baron, I've lost my pocketbook.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: There is no pocketbook here... On the floor probably.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: More than fourteen thousand marks... were in that pocketbook.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Fourteen thousand marks... One can travel -- one's happiness might depend on fourteen thousand marks -- don't you think so, Baron?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Quite possibly.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, I've got to find it.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Stay where you are.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: No -- I must find it --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: I'm all right, Doctor. There's no pain now -- only you don't know what that money means to a man like me.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: He must find his money, Baron.  Mr. Kringelein should find his pocketbook, Baron, shouldn't he?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Here -- here it is. Here's your pocketbook, Kringelein.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found it -- you found it for me, Baron.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: No -- no please -- oh, don't go -- don't go -- don't leave me alone, Baron.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Come, get up -- come let me help you.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: You're all right now -- it's very late -- goodnight, Kringelein.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay.

Speaker: doctor's voice
Dialogue: Goodnight, Baron.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Goodnight.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Flaemmchen, what are you doing here in the middle of the night.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: You live here?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: For tonight.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes -- oh!

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: And Baron, thanks so much for everything.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Flaemmchen!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You are late. I've been waiting for you -- waiting.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I had to arrange about the trip.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You're sweet.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Here, hold up!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh, no.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said: 'How do you do, Mr. Preysing! And you said:  'That was the young lady who was my secretary in Manchester'.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: That's all quite proper.  But supposing I met you when you were with your wife and I called out: "Hello you big baby -- remember Manchester?' And you with your wife, how would you like that?

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my wife out of this.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: All right. I'll get undressed -- get out.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: I must have made a mistake.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We shall soon see if you made a mistake.  Stay here... Give me that money.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: So that's how we stand, Baron.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's a matter of life or death -- I had to get some money -- tonight.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must. Humm -- humm, but you must go to jail, Baron, you're a thief.

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Be quiet.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'm going to call the police. I'm going to watch you play the great Baron with the police. Aristocrat! Aristocrat!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: The door is locked, Baron.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Hello! Hello! --

Speaker: baron
Dialogue: Don't do that.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Strike me, would you? Attack me would you? Attack me --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- I'll strike you -- Strike me!

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I strike you --

Speaker: night girl
Dialogue: Yes -- yes -- Operator -- Operator --  They are having a nice little game up there with the telephone.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein -- where are you?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- what -- what --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Quick -- something awful -- awful has happened. Go -- go at once, -- Mr. Preysing --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Preysing?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful -- it's awful.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: -- We must do something...

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes, the police must be called.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a burglar -- he was going to steal my money.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: Where is that girl -- she was working with him -- she enticed me into her room.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this -- but that girl -- the scandal -- my wife -- my daughters, you know them?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes, I know them --

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: The scandal -- we are men -- you -- you could take that affair of the young lady upon yourself -- take her and hold your tongue. Then you can travel -- I'll give you anything -- anything -- she was with you.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: We must call the police, your excellency.

Speaker: preysing
Dialogue: How much -- how much do you want -- you need money -- you have nothing.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Don't worry about me, Mr. General Director Pryesing -- worry about yourself.  There has been a murder -- this is room one sixty-four.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Hello -- hurry up... hurry up... someone in one sixty-four says there has been a murder.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Here - quick - here -- go to one sixty-four immediately.  Give me Mr. Rohna -- Rohna the manager.

Speaker: rohna
Dialogue: Where?... murder?... who?... all right, I'm coming. Wait a minute.  Instruct everyone to use the utmost tact -- we must have no scandal in the Grand Hotel. Answer no questions, I'm coming now -- inform the police.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam should sleep.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Goodnight, Suzette.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Hello -- can you tell me if Baron von Gaigern is in his room -- ring him.  ...Oh, but he must answer. Ring -- ring -- ring.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Well, ring him -- please -- please.

Speaker: baker
Dialogue: Forty-two -- forty-four -- forty-six -- forty-eight -- fifty -- fifty-two --

Speaker: baker
Dialogue: One hundred and eight -- one hundred and ten -- one hundred and twelve...

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: And the child isn't coming?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Good heavens. What for?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Most imposters are --

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: boys
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Show your hands.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Take his name -- if he comes late again today, he's fired. Dismissed!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Please, officer.

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: That will be sufficient for the present, sir, you may travel in peace.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: And they've taken him away.

Speaker: floor clerk
Dialogue: Yes -- it's terrible.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam must not know -- you understand -- Madam must not know.

Speaker: floor clerk
Dialogue: I will tell the maids. I cannot answer for downstairs --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron -- Lying there, his eyes so open.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You loved the Baron, didn't you?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: So did I. He was friendly to me as no man ever was.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Perhaps he really was a burglar -- But they don't kill a man for that.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: He was in desperate straits. He'd been trying to raise money all day. He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a man like Preysing kills him.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: I didn't like Preysing right off.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Then why did you have anything to do with him?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Money!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes, of course, -- money!

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You don't understand that do you?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Of course I do -- I never knew what money really meant till I started spending it. Do you know --  I can hardly believe that anything so beautiful should come to me from Preysing -- I'll take care of you. Will -- will you let me?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: You'll have a good time with me. Want to? I've got enough money. Ten thousand two hundred in my pocketbook. Three thousand four hundred that I won. It will last a long time. I can win more -- we'll travel.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there always.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Wherever you like. Here I'll give you the money I won, three thousand four hundred. Later you can have more.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Later?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It will not be long -- I'll not last long. Will you stay with me until...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor, he'll cure you. They can cure anything these days.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Do you believe that you will have a better time with me than you would with Preysing?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Oh yes, of course.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Do you like me better?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein -- a very good man.

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: We have to hurry let's pack -- we'll have breakfast on the train.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is waiting downstairs.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov?

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: He will be on the train.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: But when did he go? How do you know?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Baron von Gaigern has left?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: When? How long ago?

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: Oh -- Gru -- come, come -- we'll lose the train.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car...

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Come along, oh, Madam, come along. The train will be going.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: What's the use of asking, Gru -- he is at the train -- He will be there.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: The troupe, the scenery, everything -- all on board, waiting. You have a rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning. Come, Madam, are you mad?

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Have you seen Baron von Gaigern?

Speaker: rohna
Dialogue: The Baron is not here, Madam.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: He is gone?

Speaker: rohna
Dialogue: Yes, Madam.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Four minutes past. Please come.

Speaker: pimenov
Dialogue: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there -- he will be there.

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in Tremezzo --

Speaker: meierheim
Dialogue: Every seat for the opening has been sold at Vienna. Sold out for three days.

Speaker: grusinskaya
Dialogue: I know -- I know -- but it will be sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest then.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Yes, Madam.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Madam Grusinskaya's car.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: The child has come. They are both alive. My child...

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Let him take it.

Speaker: bellboy
Dialogue: Your bag, your Excellency --

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Cab please!

Speaker: bellboy
Dialogue: Cab, for his Excellency, Mr. Kringelein!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: And now we travel, Flaemmchen... Glad?

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: Am I!

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Is the bill ready -- the lady's too?

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: At once. Any forwarding address, Mr. Kringelein?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Yes, Paris -- Grand Hotel.

Speaker: flaemmchen
Dialogue: How do you know there is a Grand Hotel?

Speaker: kringelein
Dialogue: Oh, there must be one in Paris... They have everything in Paris.

Speaker: senf
Dialogue: Your bill, Your Excellency.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Was that Mr. Kringelein leaving?
